title: The Art of Blogging: Share Ideas, Build Identity
subtitle: Blogging helps you express ideas, connect with others, and build your digital identity.

content.text: A blog is a space where your ideas, knowledge, and experiences come alive through writing. It allows you to communicate with readers as if you’re having a friendly conversation — one that informs, inspires, or offers a fresh perspective.
A well-written blog doesn’t need to be complex. It just needs to be clear, meaningful, and engaging. Here’s how you can create one:
What to Include in a Good Blog

items: A clear topic — Focus on one idea that you want to share.
An engaging introduction — Explain why the topic is interesting or relevant.
Simple and structured content — Use small paragraphs, examples, or bullets to make it easy to read.
Your perspective or experience — What does this mean to you? What did you learn?
A thoughtful conclusion — Leave readers with a key takeaway or reflection.

content.text: Your voice matters. Adding personal experiences or opinions makes your blog unique and memorable.
What to Avoid While Writing

items: Going off-topic or adding unrelated information
Copying content from the internet instead of writing in your own words
Overloading with technical jargon without explanation
Writing too long without purpose or structure

content.text: Why Blogging Matters
Blogging is a powerful tool for personal branding. Every post you write becomes proof of:

items: What you know
How you think
What you care about

content.text: It helps you build credibility, showcase your skills, and connect with people beyond your usual circle. Over time, your blogs become a collection of your growth — both personal and professional.
Start small. Pick a topic you love. Write in your voice. Share your message with confidence. Your ideas might just be the reason someone learns something new today.

title: Why ITSM Will Never Go Out of Date
subtitle: Even in the age of AI and automation, IT Service Management remains irreplaceable because it connects technology with people.

content.text: In today’s world, we talk a lot about automation, AI models, and how technology is taking over repetitive work. And yes, AI can create, suggest, and even solve some basic issues on its own. But when it comes to IT Service Management (ITSM), one thing remains true: it can never completely go out of date.
Why?
Because ITSM is not just about solving technical issues. It's about understanding people, their problems, and the impact those problems have on their work.

AI models are great at generating code, building workflows, and even predicting failures. But when a user is stuck during a critical moment, they don’t just want a solution — they want assurance, clarity, and real communication.

A chatbot can tell you what to click. A human can tell you “I understand what you’re facing. Let me help you fix this.” That emotional connection is a huge part of customer satisfaction, and customer satisfaction is the backbone of every product or service delivered in the IT world.
What AI Still Can't Replace

items: Listening to user concerns
Understanding the context behind an incident
Communicating in a way that builds trust
Making decisions that include empathy
Providing reassurance during downtime or critical failures

content.text: These are not tasks AI can fully replace. They require human intelligence, not artificial intelligence.
ITSM is the Bridge Between Technology and People

Every incident, every request, every change goes through a story — a story that involves impact, urgency, fear, frustration, or relief. And humans are naturally better at dealing with all these emotions.

items: Restore productivity
Calm a stressful situation
Ensure users feel supported
Maintain the reliability of the organization’s services

content.text: This makes ITSM a timeless profession.

As AI evolves, it will take over more routine tasks. But the need for real conversations, clear communication, and empathetic support will only increase. Technology might run the systems, but humans keep the experience alive.
And at the end of the day, every organization wants one thing: Happy users.
That's why ITSM will never go out of date.

title: Formula 1: More than just cars driving in circles!
subtitle: Once you dive into Formula 1, you realize it's not just racing — it's speed, strategy, drama, and pure obsession.

content.text: Whenever I mention that I'm into F1 and ask if the other person has ever given it a shot, the number one response I get is “Isn't it just cars going around in circles?”, which is something I'm sure most if not all of the F1 heads would relate with (and they aren't even circles tbh). But the moment you dive in, you begin to realize F1 is so much more, even beyond the thrill, drama and adrenaline-pumping competition..... it's chess!

To start with the obvious, F1 cars are the fastest racing machines on the planet hitting 300+ km/h while taking corners which would snap your neck if you don't train it the way F1 racers do. Every race is a spectacle with the roaring engines, vibrant tracks around the world and breathtaking overtakes which will keep you on the edge of your seat!

But the real catch isn't just the speed — it's the lore. Every race weekend feels like a new episode in this about 9-month long series. There are fierce rivalries, unexpected plot twists, strategic gambles, dramatic controversies, heartbreaking failures and unbelievable comebacks! So even if you just want drama, this sport delivers it better than most reality shows (and it's actual reality).

And then there's the strategy. Watching an F1 race is like watching a chess match at 300 km/h. Teams make lightning-fast decisions about tyres, pit stops, fine tuning the car for every different track and even weather conditions. Even if you don’t understand everything at first, you’ll quickly find yourself predicting moves and yelling at the screen like a seasoned fan — and trust me, nothing will give you more pride than predicting a move beforehand or the commentators saying exactly what you thought a moment ago!

Best of all, the F1 community makes getting into the sport easy. You can start with race highlights or directly catch Sunday's main race called the Grand Prix, or if you're here for the drama, catch Netflix’s Drive to Survive, an F1-based documentary series. Before you know it, you’ll have a favourite team, a favourite driver and the irresistible urge to defend them no matter how humiliating of a performance they deliver...
So, give F1 a chance! One race! You might just find your next obsession you didn’t know you needed.
